Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-prt] <Cam [Trivia Challenge!]> Both Apple and Microshaft publish human interface guidelines.  There are also standards coming from different schools. 

arcane = understood by few, so it goes with "basic"   make a wallet that a peson new to cryptocurrency can understand.  

github is not currently consistent, in terms of where the pirate wallets are.  As I mentioned, the sevenseas on piratenetwork git doesn't work. 

I'm really not talking about microshaft in this instance, but predictable still applies. No matter the platform, the install process should be similar. 

And this is all coming from a perspective that I'm happy to help where I can, but I'm not a coder. I'm not trying to argue; I hope my answers give my perspective clearly.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-prt] <ùôäùôûùô£ùô†> In the run script you could include this to check if the daemon is already running:
```
count=$(/opt/pirate/pirate.sh getconnectioncount)
case $count in
    ''|*[!0-9]*) dstat=0 ;;
    *) dstat=1 ;;
esac
if [[ "$dstat" == "0" ]]; then
    /opt/pirate/start.sh
fi
```
Obviously you need to put a path parameter in there.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-prt] <PengPuffPow> @Draeth : 
https://medium.com/piratechain/the-case-for-privacy-25ed1b809dd

ZCoin employs Proof of Work with the Lyra2 algorithm, and has a total supply of 21.4 million coins. XZC uses the zerocoin algorithm, which essentially works by ‚Äúburning‚Äù a coin (and its history), and ‚Äúminting‚Äù a new coin. Zerocoin has its merits, however, it does not hide the transaction value. Moreover, zerocoin minting is an optional feature for ZCoin. At the time of this writing, less than a 10% of ZCoin‚Äôs transactions use minted coins. This leaves over 90% of the transactions as datapoints for chain analysis and reverse transaction lookup. ZCoin transactions hide the sender‚Äôs identity, however, receiver addresses and the transaction values are broadcast on the blockchain, this is only pseudo-privacy.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-prt] <jl777c> ```While the Zcoin team states in one of their blog posts explaining the issue they ‚Äúbelieve that Zerocoin can be fixed given sufficient time,‚Äù they have decided to not spend more resources to try to fix it, abandoning the protocol for a new one called Sigma. This new development has accelerated that substitution. Sigma resolves several problems Zerocoin presented, and improves the blockchain security, they claim.```

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-prt] <jl777c> ```However, electing not to wait, developers released a new mandatory security update that disables Zerocoin mints and spends in anticipation of the Sigma release. Zcoin was not the only cryptocurrency impacted. PIVX, another project that uses Zerocoin to implement privacy spends as a feature on their network, has also decided to abandon it and convert all their zPIV (the currency minted using Zerocoin) to a non-privacy coin and disable privacy spends.```
